senses.de: To propose or express willingness to do something
senses.ex: He offered to help me with my homework.

Tips.title: Voluntary Action
Tips.description: Implies that the action offered is done by choice without any pressure.
Tips.example: He offered to drive us to the airport.

Tips.title: Initiative Shown
Tips.description: Shows someone taking the initiative to help or provide service before being asked.
Tips.example: She offered her expertise on the project.

Tips.title: Polite Gesture
Tips.description: Often used to politely suggest help or support, implying good manners.
Tips.example: I offered to sort out the issue for them.

senses.de: Present or proffer something for someone to accept or reject
senses.ex: She offered me a cup of coffee.

Tips.title: Choice Given
Tips.description: Indicates giving someone a choice to accept or refuse something.
Tips.example: They offered us tea or coffee.

Tips.title: Non-binding
Tips.description: An offer does not compel you to accept; it’s not an obligation.
Tips.example: She offered her seat, but I preferred to stand.

Tips.title: Generosity Expressed
Tips.description: Making an offer can suggest generosity or a desire to be hospitable.
Tips.example: They offered their home for the party.

senses.de: Express readiness to do something for someone

Tips.title: Opportunity Extended
Tips.description: Indicates a chance or opportunity being given to someone, often professionally.
Tips.example: They offered her a scholarship to study abroad.

Tips.title: A Sign of Trust
Tips.description: Being offered something like a job can indicate trust or confidence from the offerer.
Tips.example: The company offered him a management position.

senses.de: A proposal or expression of willingness to do or give something
senses.ex: She made me a generous offer.

Tips.title: Formal Proposal
Tips.description: Often used in business or formal situations to express a serious proposition.
Tips.example: The investor made a significant offer on the property.

Tips.title: Negotiation Tool
Tips.description: Can be an initial proposal subject to further discussion and adjustment.
Tips.example: The buyer's initial offer was too low, but there's room for negotiation.

Advancement.wordDefinition:
Advancement refers to progress and improvement, usually in a professional or academic context. For example, if you receive a promotion at work or a raise in salary, that would be considered an advancement.

If you're talking about personal or professional growth, you would use advancement, while if you're talking about something that's being given or proposed to someone, you would use offer.

Bid.wordDefinition:
Bid refers to an offer to buy something that is being sold, while the word offer can be used to refer to both an offer to buy or sell something.

For example, in an auction, people will make bids to buy the item being sold. And when someone wants to sell something, they may make an offer to potential buyers.

Overall, bids are specific to buying, while offers can refer to both buying and selling.

Contribution.wordDefinition:
Contribution refers to something that is given or done by an individual or a group of people to help achieve a particular goal or accomplishment.

Contribution involves active involvement in a task or project, while an offer is the presentation of something without necessarily actively participating in the task or project.

Donation.wordDefinition:
A donation is a gift of money or goods that is made voluntarily to a charity or non-profit organization.

It is usually made out of goodwill or a desire to support a cause. Donations are also tax-deductible, which means that the donor can claim a deduction on their taxes for the amount donated.

A donation is a gift made to a charitable organization out of goodwill, while an offer is a proposal made to someone with the intention of receiving something in return.

Presentation.wordDefinition:
A presentation is a display or demonstration of information or ideas to an audience.

Presentations can be formal or informal, and can be given in various mediums, such as PowerPoint, video, or live speech.

For example, a student may give a presentation in class about a historical event.

An offer is a proposition for entering into a contract or agreement, while a presentation is a display of information or ideas.

Proposal.wordDefinition:
An offer is a formalized agreement to provide goods, services, or something of value in exchange for something else. It is a specific and definite proposal, which the other party can choose to accept or reject.

A proposal is a suggestion or plan that is put forward for consideration or discussion. It is a preliminary idea that may or may not be agreed upon, but it is often made at an earlier stage of negotiation before an offer is made.

In simpler terms, an offer is a concrete and binding proposal that is made after careful consideration, whereas a proposal is a more fluid and tentative idea that is suggested for discussion and consideration.

Offers are typically used in formal business transactions, whereas proposals may be used in a wide range of contexts, such as in personal relationships, social gatherings, or political negotiations.

Proposition.wordDefinition:
Both offer and proposition are words used to describe a suggestion or proposal.

A proposition is a proposal or suggestion for consideration or discussion.

It can be used in a variety of contexts. For example, a group of friends might make a proposition for where they want to go for dinner, or a business might propose a new marketing strategy to their clients.

An offer is a concrete proposal for a specific transaction, while a proposition is a broader suggestion or idea for discussion.

Suggestion.wordDefinition:
A suggestion is an idea or proposal for someone else to consider. For example, if you suggest to someone that they try a new type of food, you are proposing that they consider trying it.

Offers are applicable when you want to give or provide something to someone else, while suggestions are applicable when you want to propose an idea or option for someone else to consider.

Tender.wordDefinition:
The words offer and tender both mean to present something for consideration.

Tender is more specific and it usually refers to the act of presenting a formal proposal or bid in response to an invitation or request, typically in a formal setting such as a government tender or corporate Request for Proposal (RFP).

In simpler terms, offer is used when you're presenting an option in general, while tender is used when you're presenting a formal proposal or bid.
